name: Somatic Experiencing (SE)
summary: Somatic Experiencing is a body-focused therapy designed to resolve trauma and chronic stress by helping individuals release stored physiological tension and restore natural self-regulation.
description: Somatic Experiencing (SE), developed by Dr. Peter Levine, is a trauma therapy that emphasizes the body’s innate capacity to heal. It views trauma not as the event itself, but as the dysregulation of the autonomic nervous system that results from overwhelming experiences. SE uses gentle awareness of bodily sensations, movement, and the release of physical tension (discharge) to restore balance. By working with sensations rather than explicit re-exposure to trauma, SE helps clients renegotiate traumatic experiences and reestablish a sense of safety and resilience.

contraindications: Unstable medical conditions where somatic awareness may be distressing
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe; may bring up strong physical or emotional sensations, which require careful pacing and skilled facilitation.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Preliminary studies show SE can reduce PTSD symptoms, though more large-scale randomized controlled trials are needed.

sections.text: SE is based on the theory that trauma dysregulates the autonomic nervous system, trapping survival energy in the body. By guiding clients to gently observe sensations and complete interrupted defensive responses (such as fight, flight, or freeze), SE facilitates the release of stored tension and restores nervous system regulation.

sections.preparation: Establish safety, trust, and stabilization; explain the SE approach and pacing.
procedure: Guide client to notice body sensations in a safe and contained manner.
Use titration (breaking down traumatic material into manageable pieces).
Encourage pendulation (moving between states of activation and calm).
Facilitate discharge of survival energy through gentle movement, trembling, or breath.
Support integration of the experience into a sense of safety and regulation.
sections.duration: 8–20 sessions, though some clients may benefit from longer treatment.

sections.pre_session: Grounding and orienting to present safety.
sections.treatment_phase: Tracking sensations, titrating activation, and facilitating discharge of stored tension.

rare: Intensification of traumatic memories if not paced appropriately

relative: Clients with limited tolerance for body awareness exercises

ideal_candidates: Individuals with PTSD or trauma-related symptoms
Clients experiencing somatic symptoms related to stress
Those seeking body-based approaches to healing
screening_required: Evaluation of dissociation and nervous system regulation capacity

practitioner: Mental health professionals trained and certified in Somatic Experiencing

studies: Preliminary trials suggest SE reduces PTSD symptoms and improves nervous system regulation.
Pilot studies support SE in addressing chronic stress and somatic symptom disorders.
sections.limitations: Limited large-scale randomized controlled trials; more rigorous research needed.

sections.insurance_coverage: Coverage varies; some insurers classify SE under psychotherapy
sections.cost_effectiveness: Potentially cost-effective for trauma resolution compared to longer-term therapies

sections.adolescents: Useful for trauma recovery and regulation; requires adaptation for developmental level.
sections.older_adults: May help with trauma, grief, and stress-related somatic symptoms.

items: SE emphasizes titration and pacing to avoid retraumatization.
Therapists help clients track small shifts in body sensations.
Integration and grounding are critical to successful outcomes.
